# Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd
import plotly.express as px
from IPython.display import display
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load the data
file_path = 'archive/data.csv'
df = pd.read_csv(file_path)
This is picking out Ed Sheeran individually and analysing his songs over the course of his billdboard hot 100

# Display the first few rows of the DataFrame
display(df.head())

filtered_data = df[(df['artist'] == 'Ed Sheeran') & (df['song'] == 'Bad Habits')]
filtered_data = filtered_data.sort_values(by="date")

children.value:
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
plt.plot(filtered_data['date'], filtered_data['rank'])
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()  # Invert y-axis as lower ranks are better
plt.title('Ranking of "Bad Habits" by Ed Sheeran Over Time')
plt.xlabel('Date')
plt.ylabel('Billboard Rank')
plt.show()

# Find the top artist
top_artist_counts = df[df['rank'] == 1]['artist'].value_counts()
top_artist = top_artist_counts.idxmax()

# Filter the dataset for the top artist's entries
top_artist_df = df[df['artist'] == top_artist]

# Display the top artist and relevant information
print(f"Top Artist: {top_artist}")
print(top_artist_df[['song', 'peak_rank', 'weeks_on_chart']].head(5))
print("\n")

# Find the top song
top_song_counts = df[df['rank'] == 1]['song'].value_counts()
top_song = top_song_counts.idxmax()

# Filter the dataset for the top song's entries
top_song_df = df[df['song'] == top_song]

# Display the top song and relevant information
print(f"Top Song: {top_song}")
print(top_song_df[['artist', 'peak_rank', 'weeks_on_chart']].head(5))
